item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Installation of New Gold Plated RCA Plugs
item.description:
Replacing the original DIN or RCA plugs is a crucial step when restoring a Beogram 4002. The old plugs often show corrosion due to the lack of gold plating. Upgrading to modern, all-metal plugs with gold-plated terminals is recommended. This upgrade minimizes electromagnetic interference and ensures optimal signal transfer to the amplifier by maintaining low contact resistance, especially important for the delicate MMC20 cartridge signals. item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Replacing the Original DIN5 Plug with a Modern All-Metal Gold Plated Unit
item.description:
To fully restore a 4002, replacing the often corroded DIN5 connector is essential. The delicate low-voltage signals need optimal contact. Gold is an ideal material due to its resistance to oxidation, ensuring a strong and long-lasting connection. The pictures illustrate this process, showing the old connector’s condition, preparing the cable for the new connector, the soldering process, and finally, the pristine new gold-plated connector installed. item.description:

item.title: Beogram 4000: Upgrade of Signal Path with New DIN5 Plug and a Grounding Switch
item.description:
The DIN5 plug on the Beogram 4000 being restored was heavily oxidized and needed replacement. A new, fully metal plug with gold-plated terminals was installed. To improve the signal output, a switch was added to connect the signal and system grounds. This feature is beneficial when using a DIN5 to RCA adapter, as RCA cables lack a system ground. item.title: Beogram 4000: Installation of a Grounding Switch That Allows to Connect System and Signal Grounds
item.description:
During my latest restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, I encountered a loud hum when playing records through my Beomaster 6000’s 4-channel phono input. The issue was resolved by connecting the signal and system grounds. item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Replacement of Corroded RCA Plugs
item.description:
The Beogram 4002 (5523) currently under restoration was equipped with RCA plugs and a grounding wire instead of the typical DIN 5 connector. The plugs and grounding terminal were noticeably dirty and corroded. The RCA plugs were switched out for all-metal gold-plated ones, and a new grounding terminal was installed.
